newsitem.title: BRAZIL: Brazil fin min concerned at wage rise ruling.
newsitem.headline: Brazil fin min concerned at wage rise ruling.

text.p: Brazil's Finance Ministry is concerned at a ruling by the country's highest court granting 11 civil servants a 28.9 percent wage rise, a decision seen setting a precedent for the whole federal workforce, a spokesman said.
The spokesman for Finance Minister Pedro Malan said the ministry did not know what financial impact the ruling would have and would start evaluating the potential cost now.

"Obviously, judicial decisions must be respected in a democracy. But that does not erase the ministry's concern at the effects of the decision on the federal government's finances," the spokesman said.
"We now have to evaluate the impact," he said, adding the ministry did not know the full potential cost.
The spokesman noted that the 28.9 percent wage rise for 11 civil servants was "nothing" and that the decision only assumed importance if extended to the rest of the federal payroll.
The Supreme Federal Tribunal ruled 6-4 in favour of the 11 public sector workers who claimed they were entitled to a 28.9 percent pay rise awarded to the armed forces in 1993.
The ruling could set a precedent for up to one million other civil servants, who would each have to bring their own case against the government, workers' lawyers said.
The media has put the cost of the decision at $7.0 billion a year in extra payroll spending and $20 billion in backdated pay.
